clusters.title: Doctor who left patient during operation to have sex with nurse allowed to practise
clusters.neutral_headline: Doctor who left patient during operation to have sex with nurse allowed to practise: Medical tribunal rules ‘very low risk’ of Suhail Anjum, who had been dismissed by hospital in Greater Manchester, repeating behaviourA doctor who left a patient midway through an operation to have sex with a nurse is at “very low risk” of repeating his serious misconduct, a medical tribunal has ruled.Dr Suhail Anjum, 44, and the unnamed nurse were caught in a “compromising position” by a colleague who walked in on the pair at Tameside hospital. The consultant anaesthetist had asked another nursing colleague to monitor the male patient, who was under general anaesthetic, so he could go to the bathroom. Continue reading

clusters.title: The Guardian view on Merck’s exit: Britain’s biopharma strategy stalls in the face of China’s rise | Editorial
clusters.neutral_headline: The Guardian view on Merck’s exit: Britain’s biopharma strategy stalls in the face of China’s rise | Editorial: The industry’s retreat from the UK reflects a deeper shift about how Beijing is rewriting the rules of innovationWhen Merck abruptly scrapped its billion-pound London research hub last week, critics blamed Britain’s lacklustre support for life sciences and a Scrooge-like grip on NHS drug prices. But one important factor may have been missed. That Merck, which is also cutting jobs elsewhere – 6,000 globally – is recalibrating not just in response to the UK or the US, but to China.Merck’s cash cow is pembrolizumab (brand name Keytruda), an immunotherapy drug launched in 2014 that has successfully treated advanced melanoma, head and neck, lung, cervical and other cancers. It blocks an antibody called PD-1, teaching the immune system to fight the cancer. Because some patients are out of other options, the results sometimes seem miraculous.Do you have an opinion on the issues raised in this article? If you would like to submit a response of up to 300 words by email to be considered for publication in our letters section, please click here. Continue reading

clusters.title: Hospital league tables will harm, not heal, the NHS | Letters
clusters.neutral_headline: Hospital league tables may harm the National Health Service

items.title: Hospital league tables will harm, not heal, the NHS | Letters
items.standfirst: Readers respond to Wes Streeting’s introduction of hospital rankings in England based on 30 factorsWes Streeting does not seem to understand the complexity of healthcare funding. League tables will exacerbate regional differences rather than abolish them (Norfolk hospital worst in country as NHS league tables reintroduced, 9 September). The problems are not unknown but, sadly for this government, will not be solved in the next four years. It should not be a surprise, especially for Mr Streeting, that the NHS cannot function efficiently until social care is fixed.There is a massive shortage of staff in all specialities, which take 10 to 15 years to get from university to skilled professional. This leads to a reliance on locum and agency staff. The hospitals at the bottom of the tables will have the highest usage of them, reducing quality of care at a higher cost. Increasing the use of private clinics simply loses staff from the NHS. Continue reading...
items.content: Readers respond to Wes Streeting’s introduction of hospital rankings in England based on 30 factorsWes Streeting does not seem to understand the complexity of healthcare funding. League tables will exacerbate regional differences rather than abolish them (Norfolk hospital worst in country as NHS league tables reintroduced, 9 September). The problems are not unknown but, sadly for this government, will not be solved in the next four years. It should not be a surprise, especially for Mr Streeting, that the NHS cannot function efficiently until social care is fixed.There is a massive shortage of staff in all specialities, which take 10 to 15 years to get from university to skilled professional. This leads to a reliance on locum and agency staff. The hospitals at the bottom of the tables will have the highest usage of them, reducing quality of care at a higher cost. Increasing the use of private clinics simply loses staff from the NHS. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Hospital rankings could exacerbate regional differences in healthcare funding, not solve them.
Staff shortages in all specialities lead to reliance on expensive locum and agency staff.
Hospitals at the bottom of the tables will likely use more locum staff, reducing care quality.
Increasing private clinic use could draw staff away from the National Health Service.
The National Health Service cannot function efficiently until social care is fixed.

clusters.title: ‘Americans should be alarmed’: Experts say loss of expertise at CDC will harm US health
clusters.neutral_headline: Experts say loss of expertise at CDC will harm US health

items.title: ‘Americans should be alarmed’: Experts say loss of expertise at CDC will harm US health
items.standfirst: Top officials exited agency under RFK Jr’s leadership, and his anti-vax beliefs have dismayed medical communityAfter high-profile departures and sweeping layoffs, the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) faces an unprecedented loss of expertise and a simultaneous erosion of trust as top health leaders undermine vaccines and other vital health tools.“Americans should be alarmed,” said Nirav Shah, former principal deputy director at CDC and now a visiting professor at Colby College. “All of these moves leave us less safe, and it comes at a time of rising public health threats.” Continue reading...
items.content: Top officials exited agency under RFK Jr’s leadership, and his anti-vax beliefs have dismayed medical communityAfter high-profile departures and sweeping layoffs, the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) faces an unprecedented loss of expertise and a simultaneous erosion of trust as top health leaders undermine vaccines and other vital health tools.“Americans should be alarmed,” said Nirav Shah, former principal deputy director at CDC and now a visiting professor at Colby College. “All of these moves leave us less safe, and it comes at a time of rising public health threats.” Continue reading...

ai_summary: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention faces a loss of expertise.
Top officials have exited the agency under the leadership of RFK Jr.
Experts express concern about the erosion of trust in the CDC.
The departures and layoffs come amid rising public health threats.
Nirav Shah, former CDC deputy director, expressed alarm about the changes.

clusters.title: ‘One jab will do the job’: Pakistan begins rollout of HPV vaccine to millions of girls
clusters.neutral_headline: Pakistan begins rollout of HPV vaccine to millions of girls

items.title: ‘One jab will do the job’: Pakistan begins rollout of HPV vaccine to millions of girls
items.standfirst: Despite vaccination hesitancy, the end may be in sight for cervical cancer, which kills 64% of women with the diseaseThe questions come fast and furious: “Why only girls?”, “will it affect her periods?”, “can it cause infertility?”, “is it halal?” Inside the airy sports hall of Khatoon-e-Pakistan government girls’ school, the pupils in their crisp blue and white uniforms whisper among themselves, as their parents listen attentively to the health officials taking the session.While there are some fathers in the chairs laid out for the occasion, the majority are mothers. The groundwork is under way ahead of Pakistan’s first nationwide rollout of the human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccination campaign. Continue reading...
items.content: Despite vaccination hesitancy, the end may be in sight for cervical cancer, which kills 64% of women with the diseaseThe questions come fast and furious: “Why only girls?”, “will it affect her periods?”, “can it cause infertility?”, “is it halal?” Inside the airy sports hall of Khatoon-e-Pakistan government girls’ school, the pupils in their crisp blue and white uniforms whisper among themselves, as their parents listen attentively to the health officials taking the session.While there are some fathers in the chairs laid out for the occasion, the majority are mothers. The groundwork is under way ahead of Pakistan’s first nationwide rollout of the human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccination campaign. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Pakistan is starting a nationwide HPV vaccination campaign for girls.
The campaign aims to prevent cervical cancer.
Health officials are addressing parental concerns about the vaccine.
The majority of parents attending the sessions are mothers.
The HPV vaccine rollout is a significant public health initiative.

clusters.title: Mothers and babies at risk of harm in ‘toxic’ NHS cover-up culture, health leader to say
clusters.neutral_headline: Mothers and babies at risk of harm in ‘toxic’ NHS cover-up culture, health leader to say

items.title: Mothers and babies at risk of harm in ‘toxic’ NHS cover-up culture, health leader to say
items.standfirst: Head of GMC to say ‘something must have gone badly wrong’ when trainee doctors are fearful of speaking upMothers and babies being harmed in the NHS risks becoming normalised because of its toxic cover-up culture, a health leader will say, as it emerged that 14 trusts are the focus of a national maternity investigation in England.Charles Massey, the chief executive of the General Medical Council, will tell a conference on Monday that “something must have gone badly wrong” when trainee obstetrics and gynaecology doctors are fearful of speaking up.Barking, Havering and Redbridge university hospitals NHS trust.Blackpool teaching hospitals NHS foundation trust.Bradford teaching hospitals NHS foundation trust.East Kent hospitals NHS trust.Gloucestershire hospitals NHS foundation trust.Leeds teaching hospitals NHS trust.Oxford university hospitals NHS foundation trust.Sandwell and West Birmingham hospitals NHS trust.Shrewsbury and Telford hospital NHS trust.The Queen Elizabeth hospital, King’s Lynn NHS foundation trust.University hospitals of Leicester NHS trust.University hospitals of Morecambe Bay NHS foundation trust.University hospitals Sussex NHS foundation trust.Yeovil district hospital NHS foundation trust/Somerset NHS foundation trust. Continue reading...
items.content: Head of GMC to say ‘something must have gone badly wrong’ when trainee doctors are fearful of speaking upMothers and babies being harmed in the NHS risks becoming normalised because of its toxic cover-up culture, a health leader will say, as it emerged that 14 trusts are the focus of a national maternity investigation in England.Charles Massey, the chief executive of the General Medical Council, will tell a conference on Monday that “something must have gone badly wrong” when trainee obstetrics and gynaecology doctors are fearful of speaking up.Barking, Havering and Redbridge university hospitals NHS trust.Blackpool teaching hospitals NHS foundation trust.Bradford teaching hospitals NHS foundation trust.East Kent hospitals NHS trust.Gloucestershire hospitals NHS foundation trust.Leeds teaching hospitals NHS trust.Oxford university hospitals NHS foundation trust.Sandwell and West Birmingham hospitals NHS trust.Shrewsbury and Telford hospital NHS trust.The Queen Elizabeth hospital, King’s Lynn NHS foundation trust.University hospitals of Leicester NHS trust.University hospitals of Morecambe Bay NHS foundation trust.University hospitals Sussex NHS foundation trust.Yeovil district hospital NHS foundation trust/Somerset NHS foundation trust. Continue reading...

Fourteen National Health Service trusts are the focus of a national maternity investigation.
The leader will say something has gone wrong when doctors fear speaking up.

Continue reading...

items.title: Three in four English hospitals failing to hit two cancer targets in league tables
items.standfirst: Exclusive: Cancer experts declare ‘national emergency’ as hospitals miss targets on diagnosis and starting treatmentThree in four NHS hospital trusts are failing cancer patients, according to the first league tables of their kind, prompting experts to declare a “national emergency”.Labour published the first league tables to rank hospitals in England since the early 2000s this week. The overall rankings score trusts based on a range of measures including finances and patient safety, as well as how they are bringing down waiting times for operations and in A&E, and improving ambulance response times. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Get tough on tobacco and alcohol firms to improve public health | Letters
clusters.neutral_headline: Get tough on tobacco and alcohol firms to improve public health

items.title: Get tough on tobacco and alcohol firms to improve public health | Letters
items.standfirst: Hazel Cheeseman, Prof Sir Ian Gilmore and Katharine Jenner call for minimum unit pricing, a levy on profits and policies to improve food and drink. Plus a letter from Mary FoyThe “timid” approach by the government when it comes to regulating businesses is a shift from the promises of just a year ago to face down the nanny-state jibes to secure the long-term future of the NHS (Editorial, 9 September). This approach is also at odds with public sentiment. Recent polling showed 74% of people want the government to prioritise people’s health over business growth.With millions of people affected by preventable diseases caused by tobacco, alcohol and unhealthy food, we need stronger action from the government to match the rhetoric – including minimum unit pricing to prevent strong alcohol being sold cheaply, a levy on the profits of the tobacco industry and the implementation of mandatory policies to improve food and drink. Continue reading...
items.content: Hazel Cheeseman, Prof Sir Ian Gilmore and Katharine Jenner call for minimum unit pricing, a levy on profits and policies to improve food and drink. Plus a letter from Mary FoyThe “timid” approach by the government when it comes to regulating businesses is a shift from the promises of just a year ago to face down the nanny-state jibes to secure the long-term future of the NHS (Editorial, 9 September). This approach is also at odds with public sentiment. Recent polling showed 74% of people want the government to prioritise people’s health over business growth.With millions of people affected by preventable diseases caused by tobacco, alcohol and unhealthy food, we need stronger action from the government to match the rhetoric – including minimum unit pricing to prevent strong alcohol being sold cheaply, a levy on the profits of the tobacco industry and the implementation of mandatory policies to improve food and drink. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The article calls for stronger government action on tobacco and alcohol.
The authors advocate for minimum unit pricing and a levy on profits.
They also want mandatory policies to improve food and drink.
Recent polling shows public support for prioritizing health over business.
The government's approach is seen as "timid" by the authors.

clusters.title: Reasons for rise in caesarean births | Letter
clusters.neutral_headline: Factors Contributing to Increased Caesarean Births in the UK

items.title: Reasons for rise in caesarean births | Letter
items.standfirst: Simply blaming women ignores a range of clinical and societal factors that contribute to the increase in medical intervention during birth, says Dr Debbie GarrodThe rise in the rate of medically assisted births in the UK, particularly caesareans, is laid firmly at the feet of women for being older, larger and having more complex medical problems (Report, 11 September). This ignores a range of clinical and societal factors that contribute. Maternal factors play a part, but so does the rise in defensive clinical practice, the loss of midwives’ and obstetricians’ skills and confidence in supporting physiological birth, and the proliferation of misinformation and scare stories on social media that increase parental anxiety.All these factors have led us to the current crisis, where more than 50% of babies are born with surgical intervention, with no concomitant improvement in maternal or perinatal mortality and with unknown consequences for the health and wellbeing of future generations. Dr Debbie GarrodMidwife and antenatal educator, Abingdon, Oxfordshire Continue reading...
items.content: Simply blaming women ignores a range of clinical and societal factors that contribute to the increase in medical intervention during birth, says Dr Debbie GarrodThe rise in the rate of medically assisted births in the UK, particularly caesareans, is laid firmly at the feet of women for being older, larger and having more complex medical problems (Report, 11 September). This ignores a range of clinical and societal factors that contribute. Maternal factors play a part, but so does the rise in defensive clinical practice, the loss of midwives’ and obstetricians’ skills and confidence in supporting physiological birth, and the proliferation of misinformation and scare stories on social media that increase parental anxiety.All these factors have led us to the current crisis, where more than 50% of babies are born with surgical intervention, with no concomitant improvement in maternal or perinatal mortality and with unknown consequences for the health and wellbeing of future generations. Dr Debbie GarrodMidwife and antenatal educator, Abingdon, Oxfordshire Continue reading...

ai_summary: UK caesarean rates are rising, with blame often placed on women's age, size, and medical issues.
Defensive clinical practices and loss of midwife skills contribute to the rise in interventions.
Misinformation and social media scare stories increase parental anxiety about childbirth.
Over 50% of UK babies are born via surgical intervention, with no mortality improvement.
Long-term health consequences for mothers and babies from interventions remain unknown.

clusters.title: Breaking free from resentment: the hidden cost of revenge and the healing power of forgiveness | Gill Straker and Jacqui Winship
clusters.neutral_headline: Breaking free from resentment: the hidden cost of revenge and the healing power of forgiveness

items.title: Breaking free from resentment: the hidden cost of revenge and the healing power of forgiveness | Gill Straker and Jacqui Winship
items.standfirst: Chronic bitterness keeps the body in fight-or-flight mode, raising blood pressure and sapping energy. Letting go is less about virtue and more about reclaiming peace of mindThe modern mind is a column where experts discuss mental health issues they are seeing in their workFamous for his capacity to forgive his persecutors, Nelson Mandela is credited with the quote “resentment is like drinking poison and then hoping it will kill your enemies”. But many people experience a strong temptation to continue to drink the poison of resentment in vain. This often results in enduring low mood and depression that can have profound psychological, relational and physiological affects.What explains the roots of resentment and why is it so persistent? Continue reading...

ai_summary: Chronic bitterness keeps the body in fight-or-flight mode, raising blood pressure and sapping energy.
Nelson Mandela stated resentment is like drinking poison and hoping it will kill your enemies.
Many people experience a strong temptation to continue to drink the poison of resentment.
Resentment often results in enduring low mood and depression with profound effects.
The article explores the roots of resentment and why it is so persistent in people.
